text:
The transform of the object containing the chosen SOP is applied to the
    geometry.

The path to a SOP (or an Object, in which case the display SOP
        is used) which will be the initial pose for this simulation object.
Initial position in world space of the object.
Initial orientation of the object. This is in RX/RY/RZ format.
Local space position around which rotation is applied.
Initial angular velocity of the object.
Causes the Rest Geometry to be re-evaluated each frame.

The path to a SOP (or an Object, in which case the display SOP
        is used) which will be the rest geometry for this object.
Causes the Target Geometry to be re-evaluated each frame.

The path to a SOP (or an Object, in which case the display SOP
        is used) which will be the target geometry for this object.

This parameter defines how strongly the wire resists deforming from the
        animated position.

This parameter defines how strongly the wire resists oscillation
        relative to the animated position.

Determines if the mass will be calculated automatically from the
    object’s density and volume.

The mass of a wire object is its volume times its density. The
    volume is affected by the width parameter.
The absolute mass of the object.

The width of the wire object defines the diameter of each
    cylindrical section.

The coefficient of friction of the object. A value of 0 means the
    object is frictionless. This governs how much the tangential
    velocity is affected by collisions.

An object sliding may have a lower friction coefficient than an
    object at rest. This is the scale factor that relates the two. It is
    not a friction coefficient, but a scale between zero and one.

A value of one means that dynamic friction is equal to static
    friction. A scale of zero means that as soon as static friction is
    overcome the object acts without friction.
This parameter defines how strongly the wire resists stretching.

This parameter defines how strongly the wire resists oscillation due
    to stretch forces.
This parameter defines how strongly the wire resists bending.

This parameter defines how strongly the wire resists oscillation due
    to bending forces.

Enabling this parameter will adjust spring and damper strengths
    according to segment lengths. This allows wire flexibility behavior
    to be independent of segment resolution.

Enabling this parameter will adjust spring and damper strengths
    according to segment masses. This allows wire flexibility behavior
    to be independent of mass.

This parameter defines the amount of stretching allowed before the
    wire is permanently stretched.

This parameter defines how quickly a wire’s permanent shape becomes
    stretched.

This parameter defines how a wire becomes stiffer (if greater than 1) or
    weaker (if less than 1) when permanently stretched.

This parameter defines the amount of bending allowed before the
    wire is permanently bent.

This parameter defines how quickly a wire’s permanent shape becomes
    bent.

This parameter defines how a wire becomes stiffer (if greater than 1) or
    weaker (if less than 1) when permanently bent.

If enabled, the wire object will break at shared points when a segment
        stretches beyond the fracture threshold.

This is the amount of relative stretch that will cause the geometry to
        break up into separate parts during the simulation. For example, if the
        threshold is set to 0.1, then the geometry may break in places where
        there is more than 10% stretch compared to the rest geometry.

If enabled, the wire object will be prevented from touching or
        passing through any affectors that have a Volume collider label
        (e.g., RBD Objects or the ground plane). This can make the
        simulation slower.

If enabled, the wire object will be prevented from touching or
        passing through all of its wire affectors. This can make the
        simulation much slower.

If enabled, the wire object will be prevented from touching or
        passing through itself. This can make the simulation much slower.

A repulsion force is applied to gently push apart these pieces of
        geometry when the two pieces of geometry overlap (including overlap 
        of the collision width). This parameter controls the strength of
        the force.

The width that is used to calculate whether the wire 
        object has collided. This is scaled by the same point attributes 
        as the width found in the

tab. This width acts as a 
        diameter, creating a cylinder of this diameter between the end points 
        of a wire segment.
When a wire object collides with a cloth object, the

parameter in the cloth object will be used (it is used in the same
        way as described by the cloth object).

When a wire object collides with a non-wire, non-cloth object, 
        then only the wire object will have a film around it (the polygons
        in the non-wire object will be treated as having a thickness of zero).

The component of drag in the directions normal to the wire.  Increasing
        this will make the wire go along with any wind that blows against it. For
        realistic wire-wind interaction, the Normal Drag should be chosen larger
        (about 10 times larger) than the tangent drag.

The component of drag in the direction tangent to the wire.  Increasing
        this will make the wire go along with any wind that blows tangent to the
        wire.

The name of the external velocity fields on affectors that the wire will
        respond to. The default is

, which will make the wire react to fluids
        and smoke when the

have been
        chosen sufficiently large. The

forces
        are computed by comparing the wire’s velocity with the external velocity.

This offset is added to any velocity that’s read from the velocity field.
        When there’s no velocity field, then the offset can be used to create a
        wind force which has constant velocity everywhere. This wind effect is
        more realistic and more accurate than the wind that is generated by DOP
        Forces.
Turn this on to visualize the wire’s collision width in the viewport.
Turn this on to visualize the parts of the wire object which have collided, but which did not have the collision resolved.

Use this parameter to choose the color for visualizing the wire’s width in
    the viewport.

This is used to define the scale of the force lines drawn in the
    viewport. Use a small value if the lines are too long and
    distracting, and a large value if you can’t see any lines.

This is used to define the scale of the torque lines drawn in the
    viewport. Use a small value if the lines are too long and
    distracting, and a large value if you can’t see any lines.

Turn this on to see external forces, applied by DOPs Force nodes
    (such as the

Use this parameter to choose the color for external forces in the
    viewport.

Turn this on to see external torques, applied by DOPs Force nodes
    (such as the

Use this parameter to choose the color for external torques in the
    viewport.

Turn this on to see internal forces generated by a Wire Solver to
    resist stretching.

Use this parameter to choose the color for internal forces in the
    viewport.
Turn this on to see internal torques generated by a

Use this parameter to choose the color for internal torques in the
    viewport.
Turn this on to see the force preventing collisions in the viewport. This includes wire/volume collisions, wire/wire collisions and self-collisions.

Use this parameter to choose the color for collision forces in the
    viewport.
Turn this on to see forces generated by a

Use this parameter to choose the color for constraint forces in the
    viewport.
Turn this on to see torques generated by a

Use this parameter to choose the color for constraint torques in the
    viewport.
Turn this on to see impacts in the viewport. The impacts may appear in strange locations: they are shown at the position where a collision

This is used to define the scale of the lines drawn in the viewport
    to show impacts.

Use a small value if the lines are too long and
    distracting, and a large value if you can’t see the lines.
Use this parameter to choose the color for impacts in the viewport.
Use this to show all impacts during a DOPs step. The
takes many substeps per DOPs step. If this is cleared, only the impacts for the current substep are shown.
Turn this on to see each point’s orientation.

This is used to define the scale of the axis lines drawn in the
    viewport. Use a small value if the lines are too long and
    distracting, and a large value if you can’t see any lines.
Use this parameter to choose the color for local x-axis.
Use this parameter to choose the color for local y-axis.
Use this parameter to choose the color for local z-axis.
